{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Martin McGuinness |office = {{nowrap|3rd [[deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland]]}} |image = Martin McGuinness MLA.jpg |caption = Martin McGuinness in 2013 |monarch = |1blankname = Served with |1namedata = {{Ublist|[[Ian Paisley]]|[[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter Robinson]]|[[Arlene Foster]]}} |predecessor = [[Mark Durkan]] |successor = ''Vacant'' |footnotes = {{small|*[[John O'Dowd]] served as Acting dFM from 20 September 2011 to 31 October 2011 while McGuinness campaigned in the [[Irish presidential election, 2011]].}} |president1 = [[Gerry Adams]] |vicepresident1 = [[Pat Doherty]]
[[Mary Lou McDonald]] |1blankname1 = Chairman |1namedata1 = [[Mary Lou McDonald]]
[[Declan Kearney]] |office1 = [[Leader of Sinn Féin]] in [[Northern Ireland]] |predecessor1 = [[Gerry Adams]] |party = [[Sinn Féin]] |office2 = [[Department of Education (Northern Ireland)|Minister of Education]] |firstminister2 = [[David Trimble]]
[[Reg Empey]] (Acting) |1blankname2 = Deputy First Minister |1namedata2 = [[Seamus Mallon]]
[[Mark Durkan]] |predecessor2 = ''Office established'' |successor2 = [[Caitríona Ruane]] |successor1 = [[Michelle O'Neill]] |birth_name = James Martin Pacelli McGuinness |birth_date = {{birth date|1950|5|23|df=y}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]]}} |death_date = {{death date and age|2017|3|21|1950|5|23|df=y}} |death_place = Derry, Northern Ireland |spouse = {{marriage|Bernadette Canning|1974}} |children = 4 |term_start = 8 May 2007 |term_end = 9 January 2017* |term_start2 = 2 December 1999 |term_end2 = 14 October 2002 |term_start1 = 8 May 2007 |term_end1 = 23 January 2017 |office3 = [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (Northern Ireland)|Member of the Legislative Assembly]]
for [[Foyle (Assembly constituency)|Foyle]] |term_start3 = 6 May 2016 |term_end3 = 26 January 2017 |predecessor3 = [[Maeve McLaughlin]] |successor3 = [[Elisha McCallion]] |office4 = [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (Northern Ireland)|Member of the Legislative Assembly]]
for [[Mid Ulster (Assembly constituency)|Mid Ulster]] |term_start4 = 25 June 1998 |term_end4 = 6 May 2016 |predecessor4 = ''[[Good Friday Agreement|Constituency established]]'' |successor4 = [[Linda Dillon]] |office5 = [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[Mid Ulster (UK Parliament constituency)|Mid Ulster]] |term_start5 = 1 May 1997 |term_end5 = 2 January 2013 |predecessor5 = [[William McCrea (politician)|William McCrea]] |successor5 = [[Francie Molloy]] |majority5 = 15,363 (37.6%) }} '''James Martin Pacelli McGuinness''' ({{lang-ga|Séamus Máirtín Pacelli Mag Aonghusa}};{{cite press release |date=22 April 2005 |language=Irish |url=http://www.sinnfein.ie/contents/4287 |title=Ag cur Gaeilge ar ais i mbéal an phobail – Fórógra Shinn Féin do na Toghcháin Westminster |publisher=Sinn Féin press release |accessdate=21 March 2017}} 23 May 1950 – 21 March 2017) was an [[Irish republican]] [[Sinn Féin]] politician who was the [[First Minister and deputy First Minister|deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland]] from May 2007 to January 2017.[http://www.ofmdfmni.gov.uk/index/about-ofmdfm/ministers.htm About the Department] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222212413/http://www.ofmdfmni.gov.uk/index/about-ofmdfm/ministers.htm |date=22 December 2007 }} Office of the First Minister and deputy First Minister. A former [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] (IRA) leader, McGuinness was the [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Mid Ulster (UK Parliament constituency)|Mid Ulster]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]] until his resignation in 2013.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1303355.stm|title=Profile: Martin McGuinness|website=News.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2017-05-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/1230/martin-mcguinness.html |title=Martin McGuinness resigns as MP for Mid-Ulster |website=Rte.ie |date=2012-12-30 |accessdate=2017-05-04}} Like all Sinn Féin MPs, McGuinness [[abstentionism|abstained]] from participation in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Westminster Parliament]]. Following the [[St Andrews Agreement]] and the [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2007|Assembly election in 2007]], as Sinn Féin's political leader in the North, he became deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland on 8 May 2007, with the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) leader [[Ian Paisley]] becoming First Minister. On 5 June 2008 he was re-appointed as deputy First Minister to serve alongside [[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter Robinson]], who succeeded Paisley as First Minister.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/northern_ireland/7438306.stm "Robinson is new NI first minister"], BBC News, 5 June 2008. Retrieved 5 June 2008 McGuinness previously served as Minister of Education in the [[Northern Ireland Executive]] between 1999 and 2002. He was Sinn Féin's candidate for [[President of Ireland]] in the [[Irish presidential election, 2011|2011 election]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0916/president.html |title=Martin McGuinness set to be SF Áras candidate |publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann |date=16 September 2011|accessdate=28 September 2011}}{{cite news|author=GrabOne daily deals|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/mcguinness-my-pay-will-be-euro35k-irsquoll-be-peoplersquos-president-2880326.html|title=McGuinness: My pay will be €35k, I'll be people's president|work=The Irish Independent|date=18 September 2011|accessdate=28 September 2011}}{{cite news|last=Simpson|first=Mark|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/14960014|title=Martin McGuinness: Paramilitary to politician to president?|publisher=BBC|date=17 September 2011|accessdate=28 September 2011}} Working alongside US Special Envoy [[George J. Mitchell|George Mitchell]], McGuinness was also one of the main architects of the [[Good Friday Agreement]] which formally cemented the [[Northern Ireland peace process]].{{cite news|url=http://irishpost.co.uk/former-us-president-bill-clinton-pays-tribute-calm-courageous-martin-mcguinness/|title=Former US President Bill Clinton pays tribute to ‘courageous’ Martin McGuinness|newspaper=[[The Irish Post]]|accessdate=2017-05-04}} On 9 January 2017, McGuinness resigned as deputy First Minister in a protest over the [[Renewable Heat Incentive scandal]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-38561507|title=Martin McGuinness resigns as NI deputy first minister|date=9 January 2017|publisher=BBC News|access-date=9 January 2017}} He announced on 19 January that he would not be standing for re-election to the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]] in the [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2017|2 March 2017 election]] due to ill health. He reportedly suffered from [[amyloidosis]], a condition that attacks the [[vital organs]], and retired shortly before his death on 21 March 2017, aged 66.{{cite news|author=Henry McDonald |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jan/19/martin-mcguinness-to-quit-politics-to-recover-from-very-serious-illness |title=Martin McGuinness quits politics to recover from serious illness | Politics |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}}{{cite news|title=Sinn Féin's Martin McGuinness dies aged 66|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-39185899|work=BBC}} == Provisional IRA activity == McGuinness acknowledged that he was a former IRA member, but stated that he left the IRA in 1974.Henry McDonald [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2011/oct/12/ira-relative-martin-mcguinness-blood IRA victim's brother says Martin McGuinness has blood on his hands] ''[[The Guardian]]'' 12 October 2011 He originally joined the [[Official IRA]], unaware of the split at the December 1969 Army Convention, switching to the [[Provisional IRA]] soon after. By the start of 1972, at the age of 21, he was second-in-command of the IRA in [[Derry]], a position he held at the time of [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday]], when 14 civil rights protesters were killed in the city by soldiers of the [[1st Battalion, Parachute Regiment]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1308899.stm|title=BBC News – NORTHERN IRELAND – McGuinness confirms IRA role|website=New.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2017-05-04}}{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/hmso/widgery.htm|title=CAIN: [Widgery Report] Report of the Tribunal appointed to inquire into events on Sunday, 30 January 1972|work=ulst.ac.uk}} During the [[Saville Inquiry]] into the events of that day, [[Paddy Ward]] stated he had been the leader of the [[Fianna Éireann|Fianna]], the youth wing of the IRA at the time of Bloody Sunday. He said that McGuinness and an anonymous IRA member gave him bomb parts that morning. He said that his organisation intended to attack city centre premises in Derry on the same day. In response, McGuinness said the statements were "fantasy", while Gearóid Ó hEára (formerly Gerry O'Hara), a Derry [[Sinn Féin]] councillor, stated that he and not Ward was the Fianna leader at the time.John Innes, [http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=628&id=1161662003 "McGuinness is named as bomb runner"], ''[[The Scotsman]]'', 21 October 2003. The inquiry concluded that, although McGuinness was "engaged in paramilitary activity" at the time of Bloody Sunday and had probably been armed with a [[Thompson submachine gun]], there was insufficient evidence to make any finding other than they were "sure that he did not engage in any activity that provided any of the soldiers with any justification for opening fire".{{cite web|url=http://report.bloody-sunday-inquiry.org/volume01/chapter003/#the-report|title=Report of The Bloody Sunday Inquiry – Volume I – Chapter 3|publisher=Bloody Sunday Inquiry|date=15 June 2010|accessdate=15 June 2010|quote=3.119 in the course of investigating the activities of the Provisional and Official IRA on the day, we considered at some length allegations that Martin McGuinness, at that time the Adjutant of the Derry Brigade or Command of the Provisional IRA, had engaged in paramilitary activity during the day. In the end we were left in some doubt as to his movements on the day. Before the soldiers of Support Company went into the Bogside he was probably armed with a Thompson sub-machine gun, and though it is possible that he fired this weapon, there is insufficient evidence to make any finding on this, save that we are sure that he did not engage in any activity that provided any of the soldiers with any justification for opening fire.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824013430/http://report.bloody-sunday-inquiry.org/volume01/chapter003|archivedate=24 August 2010}} McGuinness negotiated alongside [[Gerry Adams]] with the [[Secretary of State for Northern Ireland]], [[William Whitelaw|Willie Whitelaw]], in 1972. In 1973, he was convicted by the [[Republic of Ireland]]'s [[Special Criminal Court]], after being arrested near a car containing {{convert|250|lb|kg}} of explosives and nearly 5,000 rounds of ammunition. He refused to recognise the court, and was sentenced to six months' imprisonment. In court, he declared his membership of the Provisional IRA without equivocation: "We have fought against the killing of our people... I am a member of [[Óglaigh na hÉireann]] and very, very proud of it".{{cite book|last=Taylor|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter Taylor (Journalist)|title=Provos The IRA & Sinn Féin|publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]]|year=1997|pages=152–53|isbn=0-7475-3818-2}} After his release, and another conviction in the Republic of Ireland for IRA membership, he became increasingly prominent in Sinn Féin, the political wing of the [[Republican movement (Ireland)|republican movement]]. He was in indirect contact with British intelligence during the [[1981 Irish hunger strike|1981 hunger strikes]], and again in the early 1990s.{{cite web|url=http://www.sinnfein.ie/contents/15216 |title=Setting the Record Straight | Sinn Féin |website=Sinnfein.ie |date= |accessdate=2017-05-04}} He was elected to the [[Northern Ireland Assembly (1982)|Northern Ireland Assembly]] at [[Parliament Building of Northern Ireland|Stormont]] in 1982, representing [[Londonderry (Assembly constituency)|Londonderry]]. He was the second candidate elected after [[John Hume]]. As with all elected members of Sinn Féin and the SDLP, he did not take up his seat.''Martin McGuinness: From Guns to Government'' by Liam Clarke and Kathryn Johnston ({{ISBN|1-84018-725-5}}), pages 152–153 On 9 December 1982, McGuinness, Gerry Adams and [[Danny Morrison (writer)|Danny Morrison]] were banned from entering Great Britain under the [[Prevention of Terrorism Act (Northern Ireland)|Prevention of Terrorism Act]] by the [[Home Secretary]], William Whitelaw.''Martin McGuinness: From Guns to Government'' by Liam Clarke and Kathryn Johnston ({{ISBN|1-84018-725-5}}), page 155 In August 1993, he was the subject of a two-part special by ''[[The Cook Report]]'', a [[ITV Central|Central TV]] investigative documentary series presented by [[Roger Cook (journalist)|Roger Cook]]. It accused him of continuing involvement in IRA activity, of attending an interrogation and of encouraging Frank Hegarty, an informer, to return to Derry from a safe house in England. Hegarty's mother Rose appeared on the programme to tell of telephone calls to McGuinness and of Hegarty's subsequent murder. McGuinness denied her account and denounced the programme saying "I have never been in the IRA. I don't have any sway over the IRA".''Martin McGuinness: From Guns to Government'' by Liam Clarke and Kathryn Johnston ({{ISBN|1-84018-725-5}}), page 222 In 2005, [[Michael McDowell (politician)|Michael McDowell]], the Irish [[Tánaiste]], stated McGuinness, along with Gerry Adams and [[Martin Ferris]], were members of the seven-man [[IRA Army Council]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1483997/Adams-and-McGuinness-named-as-IRA-leaders.html |title=Adams and McGuinness named as IRA leaders |first=Thomas |last=Harding |date=21 February 2005 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=9 May 2012 |location=London}} McGuinness denied this, saying he was no longer an IRA member. Experienced [[The Troubles|Troubles]] journalist [[Peter Taylor (journalist)|Peter Taylor]] presented further apparent evidence of McGuinness's role in the IRA in his documentary ''Age of Terror'', shown in April 2008.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7356159.stm Age of Terror], [[BBC News]], 21 April 2008 In his documentary, Taylor alleges that McGuinness was the head of the [[IRA's Northern Command]] and had advance knowledge of the IRA's 1987 [[Remembrance Day bombing|Enniskillen bombing]], which left 11 civilians dead.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7356159.stm|title=BBC NEWS – UK – Who knew about Enniskillen plans?|website=News.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2017-05-04}} == Chief negotiator and Minister of Education == He became Sinn Féin's chief negotiator in the [[Northern Ireland peace process]] negotiations which led to the [[Good Friday Agreement]]. At the time of his death, former US President Bill Clinton noted that McGuinness was the one who personally oversaw the Agreement's arms decommissioning phase.{{cite web|url=https://www.clintonfoundation.org/press-releases/statement-president-clinton-passing-martin-mcguinness|title=Statement from President Clinton on the Passing of Martin McGuinness|website=Clintonfoundation.org|accessdate=2017-05-04}} Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair also acknowledged the leading role which McGuinness had in ensuring the Agreement would be enforced.{{cite web|url=https://www.derrynow.com/news/tony-blair-martin-mcguinness-good-friday-agreement-never-achieved-without-martins-leadership-courage/151921|title=Tony Blair on Martin McGuinness - Good Friday Agreement could never have been achieved 'without Martin's leadership and courage'|website=Derrynow.com|accessdate=2017-05-04}} He was elected to the [[Northern Ireland Forum]] in 1996 representing [[Foyle (Assembly constituency)|Foyle]]. Having contested Foyle unsuccessfully at the 1983, 1987 and 1992 Westminster elections,{{cite web|title=Election Data 1987|url=http://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/electdata_1987.txt|publisher=[[Electoral Calculus]]|accessdate=18 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015054243/http://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/electdata_1987.txt|archivedate=15 October 2011}}{{cite web|title=Election Data 1983|url=http://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/electdata_1983.txt|publisher=[[Electoral Calculus]]|accessdate=18 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015054231/http://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/electdata_1983.txt|archivedate=15 October 2011}}{{cite web|title=Election Data 1992|url=http://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/electdata_1992ob.txt|publisher=[[Electoral Calculus]]|accessdate=18 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015054418/http://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/electdata_1992ob.txt|archivedate=15 October 2011}} he became MP for [[Mid Ulster (UK Parliament constituency)|Mid Ulster]] in 1997 and after the Agreement was concluded, was returned as a member of the Assembly for the [[Mid Ulster (Assembly constituency)|same constituency]], and nominated by his party for a ministerial position in the power-sharing [[Northern Ireland Executive|executive]], where he became Minister of Education. One of his controversial acts as Minister of Education was his decision to scrap the [[Eleven plus exam|11-plus exam]], which he had failed as a child.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/549635.stm. McGuinness: Let's work together] BBC News, 4 December 1999 He was re-elected to the Westminster Parliament in 2001, 2005 and 2010. In May 2003, transcripts of telephone calls between McGuinness and British officials including [[Mo Mowlam]], the then Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, and [[Jonathan Powell (Labour adviser)|Jonathan Powell]], [[Tony Blair]]'s Chief of Staff, were published in a biography of McGuinness entitled ''From Guns to Government'' by Kathryn Johnston and Liam Clarke. The tapes had been made by [[MI5]] and the authors of the book were arrested under the [[Official Secrets Act]]. The conversations showed an easy and friendly relationship between McGuinness and Powell. He joked with Powell about [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]] MPs while Mowlam referred to him as "babe" and discussed her difficulties with Blair. In another transcript, he praised [[Bill Clinton]] to Gerry Adams.{{cite web|url=http://cryptome.org/mcguinness-taps.htm |title=Martin McGuinness Wiretap Transcripts |publisher=Cryptome.org |accessdate=28 September 2011}} == St Andrews Agreement and deputy First Minister == [[File:Scottish and Northern Ireland Ministers.jpg|thumb|McGuinness, [[Ian Paisley]], and Scottish First Minister [[Alex Salmond]] in 2008]] [[File:President Barack Obama meets Northern Ireland First Minister Peter Robinson and Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness.jpg|thumb|United States President [[Barack Obama]] with [[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter Robinson]] and McGuinness in March 2009]] In the weeks following the [[St Andrews Agreement]], the four biggest parties—the DUP, Sinn Féin, the UUP and the SDLP—indicated their choice of ministries in the Executive and nominated members to fill them. The Assembly convened on 8 May 2007 and Paisley and McGuinness were nominated as First Minister and deputy First Minister respectively. On 12 May Sinn Féin agreed to take up three places on the [[Northern Ireland Policing Board]], and nominated three MLAs to take them.{{cite web|last1=Wilford|first1=Rick|last2=Wilson|first2=Robin|title=Devolution Monitoring Programme 2006–08|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/constitution-unit/research/research-archive/ni07.pdf|publisher=Queens University Belfast|accessdate=21 March 2017}}{{cite book|last1=Lansford|first1=Tom|title=Political Handbook of the World 2012|year=2012|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-1-6087-1995-2|pages=1138–1139}} On 8 December 2007, while visiting President of the United States [[George W. Bush]] in the [[White House]] with the Northern Ireland First Minister Ian Paisley, McGuinness said to the press, "Up until the 26 March this year, Ian Paisley and I never had a conversation about anything—not even about the weather—and now we have worked very closely together over the last seven months and there's been no angry words between us.... This shows we are set for a new course."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7123939.stm Paisley and McGuinness in US trip] BBC News, 3 December 2007Martina Purdy [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7134094.stm 'Charming' ministers woo president] BBC News, 8 December 2007 == 2011 Irish presidential campaign == {{Main|Irish presidential election, 2011}} On 16 September 2011 McGuinness was announced as the Sinn Féin candidate in the 2011 Irish presidential election.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2011/sep/16/martin-mcguinness-irish-presidency | title=Martin McGuinness to run for Irish presidency |date=16 September 2011|work=The Guardian|accessdate=16 September 2011 |location=London |first=Henry |last=McDonald}}{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ireland/8770384/Martin-McGuinness-to-run-for-president-of-Ireland.html | title=Martin McGuinness to run for president of Ireland |date=17 September 2011|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2011 |location=London}} In the election held on 27 October, McGuinness placed third in the first preference vote, behind [[Michael D. Higgins]] and [[Seán Gallagher]].[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5hIyv_KVIRSAkDAz3PM0W0n8jvpog?docId=N0338681319824478604A]{{dead link|date=August 2016}} McGuinness was the only candidate ineligible to vote in the election as, although an [[Irish citizen]], he was not ordinarily resident in the [[Republic of Ireland]].{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/presidential-election/mcguinness-unable-to-vote-for-himself-2919695.html | work=Irish Independent | title=McGuinness unable to vote for himself | date=28 October 2011}} Following his defeat, McGuinness formally returned to the role of deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland on 31 October.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-15527135 | publisher=BBC News | title=Martin McGuinness returns as deputy first minister | date=31 October 2011}} == Resignation from the House of Commons == On 30 December 2012 McGuinness announced that he had formally resigned as the MP for Mid-Ulster stating "I have served formal notice of my resignation from the position of MP for Mid-Ulster with immediate effect. This is in line with my party's commitment to end [[double jobbing]]."[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20871049 "Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness resigns as Mid-Ulster MP"], BBC News To do this, he was made [[Steward of the Manor of Northstead]] on 2 January 2013 by Chancellor [[George Osborne]], making him an employee of the Crown and thus ineligible for membership of the House of Commons.{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2013/0102/breaking32.html | work=The Irish Times|title=McGuinness awarded British title}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/press_01_13.htm |title=Manor of Northstead|publisher=HM Treasury |date=2 January 2013 |accessdate=31 March 2013}} == Resignation as deputy First Minister == {{Main|Renewable Heat Incentive scandal}} [[File:Martin McGuinness and Michelle O'Neill.jpg|thumb|[[Michelle O'Neill]] replaced McGuinness as Sinn Féin's leader in the Northern Ireland Assembly in January 2017]] In November 2016, a scandal came to light surrounding the Renewable Heat Incentive, an energy incentive championed by [[Arlene Foster]] when she was [[Department for the Economy|Minister for Enterprise, Trade, and Incentives]] in 2012. The incentive would cost the Northern Ireland Executive £480m over 20 years, and was marred by allegations of fraud, which were not acknowledged or acted upon by Foster or the DUP.{{cite news|last1=Macauley|first1=Conor|title=Renewable Heat Incentive scheme: Whistleblower 'ignored' after reporting abuse claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-37925402|work=BBC News|date=9 November 2016}} McGuinness and others in Sinn Féin called for Foster (now First Minister) to step aside to allow for independent inquiries, but Foster refused.{{cite news|title=Sinn Féin to table motion calling on Northern Irish First Minister to stand aside|url=http://www.newstalk.com/reader/47.301/89159/0/|work=newstalk.com}}{{cite news|title=RHI scandal: Foster rejects Sinn Fein proposal to step aside during probe|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/business/rhi-scandal-foster-rejects-sinn-fein-proposal-to-step-aside-during-probe-1-7761880|work=Newsletter.co.uk}} Foster made a statement before the Assembly on 19 December without McGuinness' approval (as required under the power-sharing agreement), resulting in Sinn Féin and the opposition parties all walking out of the Assembly.{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Gareth|title=Robin Newton: 'Concerns recognised' over RHI statement|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-38373619|work=BBC News|date=20 December 2016}} Sinn Féin President [[Gerry Adams]] indicated on 8 January 2017 that McGuinness could resign, thus vacating both his and Foster's offices, if Foster did not agree to temporarily step aside to allow an independent inquiry.{{cite news|title=RHI scandal: Gerry Adams says Sinn Féin will act over fiasco|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-38541704|work=BBC News|date=8 January 2017}} McGuinness resigned the following day; in his statements to the press, he said "Today is the right time to call a halt to the DUP's arrogance", and said that Foster had a "clear conflict of interest" in the affair. Another reason cited for his resignation was the decision by DUP [[Department for Communities|Minister for Communities]] [[Paul Givan]] to remove £50,000 in funding from the [[Liofa]] Gaeltacht Bursary scheme, a yearly programme that allowed 100 school-age children to travel to the [[Gaeltacht#Donegal Gaeltacht|Donegal Gaeltacht]] to learn the [[Irish language]].{{cite news|title=Irish language bursary funding 'found' says Paul Givan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-38594609|work=BBC News|date=12 January 2017}} Sinn Féin refused to nominate a successor to McGuinness before 16 January, resulting in the [[Secretary of State for Northern Ireland]], [[James Brokenshire]], calling for [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2017|new elections]] scheduled for 2 March.{{cite news|title=Elections to be held in NI on 2 March|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-38641857|work=BBC News|date=16 January 2017}} McGuinness subsequently announced that he would not run for re-election, due to ill health. == Personal life == One of McGuinness's middle names, Pacelli, is after [[Pope Pius XII]] (Eugenio Pacelli).{{cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-politics-38640430 | publisher = BBC News | title = Obituary: Martin McGuinness | date = 21 March 2017 |accessdate = 21 March 2017 }} McGuinness attended first St. Eugene's Primary School and later the Christian Brothers technical college, leaving school at the age of 15.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/feb/12/northernireland.schools |title=McGuinness strives for top marks |last=Woodward |first=Will |publication-date=13 February 2001 |agency=Guardian News and Media Limited |access-date=5 December 2016}} McGuinness married Bernadette Canning in 1974; they had four children, two girls and two boys.Hardliners vent their fury at Martin McGuinness The Guardian, 14 March 2009 He was a fan of the [[Derry GAA|Derry]] [[Gaelic football]] and [[hurling]] teams{{cite news|first=Martin|last=McGuinness|title=Fanzone – Martin McGuinness|work=[[Irish Independent]]|date=26 August 2001|accessdate=6 August 2009|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/fanzone-510029.html}} and played both sports when he was younger. He grew up just 50 metres from [[Celtic Park, Derry|Celtic Park]], the home of Derry's [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] (GAA). His older brother [[Tom McGuinness (Gaelic footballer)|Tom]] played Gaelic football for Derry and is regarded as one of the county's best ever players.{{cite news|title=Ulster's 125 – Derry shortlist|work=[[The Irish News]]|date=10 February 2009|accessdate=7 April 2009|url=http://irishnews125.blogspot.com/2009/02/125-derry-player-list.html}} He had three [[Ulster Senior Football Championship]] medals, as well as [[Ulster Under-21 Football Championship|Ulster Under 21]] and [[All-Ireland Under-21 Football Championship|All-Ireland Under 21 Championship]] medals.{{Cite journal|publisher=A-Star Design|date=28 March 2009|journal=Red Hand View – Tyrone vs Derry (National League Division 1 Round 6 programme)|title=Derry Greats – Tom McGuinness}} He supported [[Derry City F.C.]] where his younger brother Paul played for the Candystripes.{{cite news|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,,468041,00.html |location=London, UK |work=The Guardian |title=My team |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209213349/http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0%2C%2C468041%2C00.html |archivedate= 9 December 2007 |df= }} McGuinness supported [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] from the age of eight.{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/other-sports/martin-mcguinness-i-brought-ulster-luck-in-the-99-euro-final-16156859.html|title=Martin McGuinness: I brought Ulster luck in the '99 Euro final|work=The Belfast Telegraph}} McGuinness also had an interest in [[cricket]] – sometimes extending his support to the [[England cricket team]], as well as that of Ireland.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2012/jan/25/martin-mcguinness-love-of-cricket|location=London|work=The Guardian|first=Patrick|last=Kingsley|title=Martin McGuinness: How I fell in love with cricket|date=25 January 2012}} ==Health concerns and death== {{commonscat|Funeral of Martin McGuinness}} [[File:Funeral of Martin McGuinness (Gerry Adams, Michelle O'Neill, Mary Lou McDonald).jpg|thumb|The funeral procession of McGuinness. Coffin bearers include [[Gerry Adams]], [[Michelle O'Neill]] and [[Mary Lou McDonald]]]] McGuinness was a member of the [[Pioneer Total Abstinence Association]], which meant that he did not drink alcohol.''Martin McGuinness: From Guns to Government'' by Liam Clarke and Kathryn Johnston ({{ISBN|1-84018-725-5}}) In December 2016, McGuinness was advised against making a planned visit to China on medical grounds,{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/19/sinn-feins-martin-mcguinness-quits-frontline-politics-recover/|title=Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness says 'very serious illness' has forced him to quit frontline politics|work=Daily Telegraph|first=Peter|last=Dominiczak|date=19 January 2017|accessdate=19 January 2017}} initially announcing that this was due to "unforeseen personal circumstances".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-38194736|title=Martin McGuinness pulls out of China trip|date=3 December 2016|accessdate=20 January 2017}} After subsequent tests, he was told that he was suffering from "a very serious illness". McGuinness and Sinn Féin declined to give details of his illness to the media.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/sf-silent-on-mcguinness-illness-1-7742178|title=SF silent on McGuinness' illness|work=Newsletter|date=21 December 2016|accessdate=19 January 2017}} In January 2017, ''[[The Irish Times]]'' disclosed that McGuinness was suffering from [[amyloidosis]], a rare incurable disease that affects organs. McGuinness complained that the ''Times'' had breached his privacy.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishcentral.com/news/politics/martin-mcguinness-slams-irish-times-for-revealing-medical-diagnosis|title=Martin McGuinness slams Irish Times for revealing medical diagnosis|publisher=IrishCentral|accessdate=16 January 2017|date=13 January 2017}} On 6 March 2017 McGuinness was hospitalised at Derry's [[Altnagelvin Area Hospital]] due to ill health.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/martin-mcguinness-latest-seriously-ill-hospital-northern-ireland-sinn-fein-deputy-first-minister-a7614171.html|title=Martin McGuinness: Former Northern Irish First Minister seriously ill in hospital|publisher=The Independent|date=6 March 2017|accessdate=20 March 2017}} He died on 21 March, at the age of 66.{{cite news|title=Sinn Féin's Martin McGuinness dies aged 66|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-39185899|accessdate=21 March 2017|agency=BBC}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/amp/861287/|title=Death announced of Martin McGuinness|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]|date=21 March 2017|accessdate=21 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/mcguinnesss-refusal-to-live-in-past-is-a-great-lesson-for-us-all-clinton-leads-the-tributes-35554011.html|title='McGuinness's refusal to live in past is a great lesson for us all' - Clinton leads the tributes|date=22 March 2017|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=22 March 2017}} ==See also== *[[Northern Ireland peace process]] *[[Operation Taurus]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Clarke, Johnston; Clarke, Liam. (2003). ''Martin McGuinness: From Guns to Government''. {{Infobox musical artist | name = Martin Musaubach | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = Martin_Musaubach_at_Riverside_Caf%C3%A9_Taipei%2C_Aug_31_2013_2.jpg | caption = Martin "Musa" Musaubach | alias = Musa | birth_date = {{birth_date_and_age|1982|5|23}} | birth_place = [[La Plata]], [[Argentina]] | Genre = [[Latin music (genre)|Latin]], [[Jazz]], [[Blues]], [[Fusion (music)|Fusion]] | occupation = Pianist, keyboardist, composer, arranger, producer | instrument = [[piano]] | years_active = 2007–present | label = Studio 3690 | associated_acts = [[MUSA's]], [[SENSATION (music project)|SENSATION]] | website = http://www.musaubach.com/ Musaubach homepage }} '''Martin "Musa" Musaubach'''(born May 23, 1982 in [[La Plata]], [[Argentina]]) is an Argentine band-leading pianist, composer, arranger and producer in [[MUSA's]]. ==About== Musa has been learning, studying and working as keyboardist since very young age. He was the member of jazz, blues and Latin music bands including Labrusca, Zoe, 5 Australes, Reina Venus, Blues Oil and Bin Bin, which Labrusca was the first band he joined in his hometown La Plata—he was only at the early age of 13, as a keyboardist and the youngest member in the band.{{Cite web |url=http://www.studiologic-music.com/musicians/martin-musaubach.html |title=Musicians: Martin Musaubach @Studiologic Music | accessdate=2013-09-26 |work=Studiologic Music |date=2013-05-10}}Introducted from Martin Musaubach studio album "3690" (released Aug 16 2013 under AsiaMuse Entertainment) From around 2007 Musa started his career in [[China]] playing live music in some famous jazz bars with his band members as MUSAS. By 2011 he was the Musical Director in Shangri-La Summit Wing Hotel ([[Beijing]]), and leading his own Latin jazz band MUSA's Trio with bass/ double bassist [[Lautaro Bellucca|Lautaro "LuKa" Bellucca]] and drummer/ percussionist [[Adriano Moreira (Gaofei)|Adriano "Gaofei" Moreira]]. In the 3rd quarter of 2011, accompanied by LuKa and Gaofei, Musa moved to [[Taipei]] to join ''Gary Chaw Project SENSATION'' (the band, so as a music project) as the key pianist and composer with the Malaysian Chinese vocalist [[Gary Chaw]] and Taiwanese compose-producer Michael Tu.台灣壹週刊 Next Magazine Taiwan #581 (2012/07/12) - p.194 - 紅男綠女「音樂讓我們相遇 Sensation」 Musa is now living in Taipei as his new home and working location, continued to play music in local jazz bars and venues with his bandmates and different musicians, at the same time collaborating with mainstream record labels and artists in live performing or recording albums. ==Releases== * '''Album''' ''3690'' - debut studio album - Aug 16 2013 {{Track listing | collapsed = no | headline = | extra_column = | total_length = | all_writing = | all_lyrics = | all_music = | writing_credits = | lyrics_credits = | music_credits = | title1 = Blues for Labrusca | note1 = | writer1 = | lyrics1 = | music1 = | extra1 = | length1 = 5:19 | title2= Distance | note2 = | writer2= | lyrics2= | music2= | extra2= | length2= 8:13 | title3 = Mamila | note3 = | writer3= | lyrics3 = | music3 = | extra3 = | length3 = 7:15 | title4 = Knetliges | note4 = | writer4 = | lyrics4 = | music4 = | extra4 = | length4 = 7:01 | title5 = The Excuse | note5 = | writer5 = | lyrics5 = | music5 = | extra5 = | length5 = 3:15 | title6 = Latineando! | note6 = Bellucca | writer6 = | lyrics6 = | music6 = | extra6 = | length6 = 5:32 | title7 = 3690 | note7 = | writer7 = | lyrics7 = | music7 = | extra7 = | length7 = 4:05 | title8 = Eyes to Heaven feat. Mandy Gaines | note8 = Gaines | writer8 = | lyrics8 = | music8 = | extra8 = | length8 = 5:31 }}

{{Infobox mountaineer | name = Mostafa Salameh | image = Mostafa Salameh completing the 7 summits.jpg | caption = Mostafa Salameh completing the {{nowrap|[[Seven Summits]]}} | main_discipline = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1970|06|25}} | nationality = Jordanian | start_age = 34 | notable_ascents = Seven Summits and Two Poles }}
'''Mostafa Salameh''', {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Order of the Star of Jordan|OSJ]]}} (born June{{nbsp}}25, 1970) is a Jordanian mountaineer who has completed the [[Seven Summits]], including [[Mount Everest]] in 2008.<ref name="Mount Everest The British Story">{{cite web|title=Mount Everest Facts|url=http://www.everest1953.co.uk/facts.html|website=Mount Everest The British Story|accessdate=25 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802092244/http://www.everest1953.co.uk/facts.html|archivedate=2 August 2014|df=}}</ref> Salameh is also a motivational speaker.
== Biography ==
Salameh first became interested in mountaineering in 2004 while working as a food and beverage manager at the Sheraton Hotel in Edinburgh, Scotland. His interest started when he had a dream of himself praying on top of Mt. Everest. His first climb in the Himalaya was in April 2004, when he tried to climb [[Mera Peak]] ({{convert|6,500|m}}) in Nepal, but had to retreat just {{convert|200|m}} from the top because of illness.<ref name="Arab Irish Journal">{{cite web|title=Onwards & Upwards|url=http://www.jaicc.ie/sites/jaicc.test.drupal.web.ie/files/Arab%20Irish%20Journal.pdf|work=the arab irish journal – Arab-Irish Chamber of Commerce|pages=50–55|year=2013}}</ref> His ascent of Everest was finally made on May{{nbsp}}25, 2008, Jordan Independence Day, after he had sold some of his possessions to fund the expedition.<ref name="IE">{{cite web|title='I rang the King of Jordan from the top of Everest'|url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/i-rang-the-king-of-jordan-from-the-top-of-everest-26734224.html|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=20 May 2011}}</ref> He rang his parents and the King of Jordan via satellite phone from the peak.<ref name="IE"/>
He completed the "Seven Summits" on November{{nbsp}}16, 2012 and is now among the (as of 2012) 235 people in the world at the time to have stood on top of the highest peak on every continent.<ref name="Jordan Times">{{cite news|title=Jordanian climber tackles Seven Summits|url=http://jordantimes.com/jordanian-climber-tackles-seven-summits|newspaper=Jordan Times|date=31 January 2013|author=Muath Freij|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115228/http://jordantimes.com/jordanian-climber-tackles-seven-summits|archivedate=26 August 2014|df=}}</ref> He reached the North Pole on April 19, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=meet our 2014 north pole teams|url=http://polarexplorers.com/polarexplorers-media/blog/north-pole/item/46-meet-our-2014-north-pole-teams|website=Polar Explorers|accessdate=26 June 2014|date=28 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819185902/http://polarexplorers.com/polarexplorers-media/blog/north-pole/item/46-meet-our-2014-north-pole-teams|archivedate=19 August 2014|df=}}</ref>
In 2008, Mostafa was awarded the [[Order of Independence (Jordan)|Independence Medal]] by King [[Abdullah II of Jordan]] for his ascent of Everest.<ref name=7iberDotCom>{{cite web|title=UPDATE: Climber Knighted By HM King Abdullah|url=http://www.7iber.org/2008/10/update-climber-knighted-by-hm-king-abdullah/#disqus_thread|website=7iberDotCom|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> His Royal Highness Ali Ibn Al Hussein and HRH Princess Haya Bint Al Hussein, the King’s brother and sister respectively, have also been major supporters.<ref name="Arab Irish Journal" />
He reached South Pole on January 15, 2016.<ref name="Adopted Scot and First Muslim">{{cite web|title=Adopted Scot and First Muslim|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/just-brrrrilliant-adopted-scot-first-7213312#ySirqth6hHFTl0IY.97}}</ref> He is now 1 of 16 people in the world who completed the [[Explorers Grand Slam]].
== Motivational speaking == Mostafa acts as a motivational speaker, addressing youths, corporate management and employees through direct comparisons between summit expeditions and daily life experiences. He focuses on themes such as team building, leadership, motivation and facing personal fears.<ref name="Mostafa Salameh">{{cite web|title=Public Speaking|url=http://www.mostafasalameh.com/speaking|work=Mostafa Salameh|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030170053/http://www.mostafasalameh.com/speaking|archivedate=2013-10-30|df=}}</ref> He names as his role models the philosopher [[Al Razi]], the explorer [[Ibn Battuta]], the philosopher, mathematician, physician and musician [[Al Kindi]], the poet, jurist and theologian [[Rumi]] and the late [[King Hussein]].<ref name="Arab Irish Journal" /> He had also come to Birla Public School in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]] for a small speech as a part of a fund to aid relief in Gaza.
== LH4 cancer initiative ==
[[File:A team of Jordanians in an expedition at Moshi, Mount Kilimanjaro.jpg|thumb|right|260px|The Jordanian expedition team at [[Mount Kilimanjaro]]]]
In 2012, Mostafa launched the "From the Lowest Point to the Highest Point for Cancer" initiative, where he led a group of 20 individuals to [[Everest Base Camp#South Base Camp|Everest Base Camp]] in Nepal in April 2013, raising $620,000 for the [[King Hussein Cancer Center]] (KHCC), and again in February 2014, when he led another group of Jordanians to the summit of [[Mount Kilimanjaro]] in Tanzania raising $1,400,000.00 for the benefit of the KHCC.<ref name="Arab Irish Journal" /><ref name=LH4Cancer />
== Education == * B.A. International Hospitality & Tourism Management – [[Queen Margaret University]] in Edinburgh (2001) * B.A. Hotel Management – Hotel Management College Amman (1992)<ref name=LH4Cancer>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.lh4cancer.com/aboutUs.html|website=Lowest to Highest for Cancer|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>
== Climbs ==
* June 2004 – Highest point in North America, [[Mount McKinley]] (20,320 ft) 6193.536 meter * January 2005 – Highest point in Antarctica [[Vinson Massif]] (16,050 ft) 5140 Meter * March 2005 – First attempt at Mount Everest (reached 23,000 ft); uncompleted due to stomach ulcer * September 2005 – Highest point in Europe [[Mount Elbrus]](18,510 ft) 5642 Meter * July 2006 – Climbed the highest point in Western Europe [[Mont Blanc]] * March 2007 – 2nd attempt at Mount Everest ... uncompleted due to chest infection * July 2007 – Climbed the highest point in Africa [[Mount Kilimanjaro]] 19,331 feet, 5895 Meters * February 2008 – Climbed the highest point in South America [[Aconcagua]] 22,841 feet, 6960 Meter<ref name=LH4Cancer /> * May 25, 2008 @ 6:50 am- Climbed the highest point in the world, Mount Everest 29,500) – Jordan Independence day * November 16, 2012 – Climbed the highest point in the Australia/Oceana continent, [[Carstensz Pyramid]], (4,884 meters / 16,023 feet) * April 2013 – Everest Base Camp: Climbed to the Base Camp of Everest with a group of Jordanians for the support of the [[King Hussein Cancer Center]] (From the Lowest to the Highest for Cancer) * February 2014 – Kilimanjaro Summit: Climbed the highest point in Africa (Kilimanjaro) with a team of 26 Jordanians for the support of the King Hussein Cancer Center (From the Lowest to the Highest for Cancer) * April 19, 2014 – Reached the [[North Pole]] on a skiing trip<ref>{{cite web|title=The Skiers Make Great Headway|url=http://www.polarexplorers.com/polarexplorers-media/blog/north-pole/item/62-the-skiers-make-great-headway|publisher=Polar Explorers|accessdate=26 June 2014|date=17 April 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084534/http://www.polarexplorers.com/polarexplorers-media/blog/north-pole/item/62-the-skiers-make-great-headway|archivedate=19 August 2014|df=}}</ref> * January 15, 2016 - Reached the [[South Pole]] <ref name="Adopted Scot and First Muslim"/>
== Recognition == * Knighted by King Abdullah of Jordan (October 6, 2008)
==Bibliography==
He has authored the book, ''Dreams of a Refugee: From the Middle East to Mount Everest''.
*{{Citation | last= Salameh| first= Mostafa | year=2016 | title= Dreams of a Refugee: From the Middle East to Mount Everest | publisher= Bloomsbury Continuum | isbn= 978-1472927514 | url= https://books.google.lk/books/about/Dreams_of_a_Refugee.html?id=HdvasgEACAAJ&redir_esc=y }}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Nadim Kobeissi | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Nadim Kobeissi.jpg | image_size = | caption = Nadim Kobeissi in 2015 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1990}} | birth_place = [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = [[Paris]], [[France]] | citizenship = Lebanon | fields = [[Computer science]], [[Cryptography]] | workplaces = [[New York University]]
[[Microsoft Research]] | patrons = [[New America Foundation]] | education = [[Political Science]] (BA)
[[Philosophy]] (BA)
[[Computer science]] (PhD) | alma_mater = [[Concordia University]]
[[French Institute for Research in Computer Science and Automation]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Cryptocat]] | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Webby Award]]{{cite web|url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current_honorees.php?media_id=96&category_id=743&season=16|title=16th Annual Webby Awards Official Honorees|publisher=}} | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = | partner = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|https://nadim.computer}} | footnotes = }} '''Nadim Kobeissi''' (born 1990) is a computer science researcher specialized in [[applied cryptography]] and a professor at [[New York University]]'s Paris campus. He is the author of [[Cryptocat]], an open-source encrypted web chat client. Kobeissi is also known for speaking publicly against [[Internet censorship]] and [[Internet surveillance]].{{cite web|url=http://newint.org/blog/2013/06/21/prism-surveillance-nsa-software/|title=How to fight PRISM|date=21 June 2013|publisher=}} ==Early life and education== Kobeissi was born in [[Beirut]], Lebanon. He studied psychology at the [[Lebanese American University]] in Beirut from 2008–2009, and graduated with a double major in political science and philosophy at [[Concordia University]] in Montreal in 2013.[http://db.nadim.cc/resume.pdf Resumé], nadim.cc. Retrieved 12 May 2012. After that he was a PhD student studying applied cryptography at the [[French Institute for Research in Computer Science and Automation]] (Inria), in France {{cite web|url=https://nadim.computer/|title=Nadim Kobeissi|website=nadim.computer}} and worked at [[Microsoft Research]] in [[Cambridge]], [[United Kingdom]]. ==Research== Kobeissi is the primary author of Cryptocat. In 2012, he presented Cryptocat at the [[Hackers on Planet Earth|HOPE]] hacker conference in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.hopenumbernine.net/schedule/#whybrowser|title=Schedule - HOPE Number 9|website=www.hopenumbernine.net}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r95Apc5riyE|title=Nadim Kobeissi HOPE 9 Why Browser Cryptography Is Bad & How We Can Make It Great|first=|last=TheEthanwashere|date=1 October 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}} During the following year, Kobeissi presented Cryptocat-related talks and research at [[Google]]'s Internet at Liberty conference,{{cite web|url=http://netizenproject.org/2012/06/10/cryptocat-and-internet-freedom-innovation/|title=Page not found – Netizen Project|publisher=}} Beirut's SHARE conference,{{cite web|url=http://www.shareconference.net/en/talk/cryptocat-nadim-kobeissi|title=Cryptocat - Nadim Kobeissi - SHARE Foundation|first=Fermicoding Internet Engineering,|last=www.fermicoding.com|website=www.shareconference.net}} the [[Chaos Computer Club]]'s SIGINT2013 conference,{{cite web|url=http://sigint.ccc.de/schedule/speakers/3812.html|title=Cryptocat: The Social and Technical Challenges of Making Crypto Accessible to Everyone|publisher=}} at RightsCon in Rio de Janeiro,{{cite web|url=https://blog.crypto.cat/2012/06/a-cryptocat-spring/|title=A Cryptocat Spring|publisher=}} and at Republika in Rijeka, Croatia.http://www.republika.io/en/performer/103?width=560&height=80%2525&iframe=true Nadim Kobeissi: Cryptocat Kobeissi is also known for discovering a privacy issue in [[Windows 8]], in which the operating system automatically reported to Microsoft what applications users were installing in an insecure fashion. Kobeissi's research was picked up by [[Gizmodo]]{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/5937649/windows-8-tells-microsoft-about-everything-you-install-not-very-securely|title=Windows 8 Tells Microsoft About Everything You Install, Not Very Securely|first=Nadim|last=Kobeissi|publisher=}} and Microsoft issued a response.{{cite web|url=http://bgr.com/2012/08/24/windows-8-privacy-microsoft-smartscreen/|title=Windows 8 sends Microsoft information about every program you install [updated]|first=Dan|last=Graziano|date=24 August 2012|publisher=}} Kobeissi is also a known proponent of browser cryptography{{cite web|url=http://blog.nadim.computer/post/84140092153/thoughts-on-critiques-of-javascript-cryptography|title=Thoughts on Critiques of JavaScript Cryptography|publisher=}} and is a member of the [[W3C]]'s Web Cryptography Working Group.{{cite web|url=https://www.w3.org/2000/09/dbwg/details?group=54174&public=1&order=org|title=Participants in the Web Cryptography Working Group - DBWG, the Working Groups Database|website=www.w3.org}} ==Activism== In 2010, Kobeissi was one of the earliest supporters of the [[Chelsea Manning#Impact and reception|Bradley Manning Support Network]].[[Denver Nicks|Nicks, Denver]] (2012). ''Private: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks, and the Biggest Exposure of Official Secrets in American History''. Chicago Review Press, p. 223. He organized a march through Montreal in December that year in support of [[WikiLeaks]], ran a WikiLeaks mirror site, and defended WikiLeaks on various Canadian news publications.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2010/12/08/wikileaks-mirror-site-in-montreal.html|title=Montreal student hosts mirror WikiLeaks site|publisher=}} During 2011 and 2012, Kobeissi hosted CHOMP.FM, a radio program on Internet activism that ran weekly on Montreal's [[CKUT-FM]] radio station. The show included guests from the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF), security researcher [[Bruce Schneier]], and journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]].For the march, see Shingler, Benjamin (18 December 2010). [http://m.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/quebec/demonstrators-march-to-support-wikileaks-in-montreal/article1843691/?service=mobile "Demonstrators march to support WikiLeaks in Montreal"], The Canadian Press. *For the mirror site, see {{cite news | title=Montreal student hosts mirror WikiLeaks site | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2010/12/08/wikileaks-mirror-site-in-montreal.html | newspaper=CBC News |date=8 December 2012}} *{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Magder | title=Proposed changes to copyright law go too far, protesters say | url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/business/Proposed+changes+copyright+protesters/6137394/story.html | newspaper=Montréal Gazette |date=11 February 2012}} In 2013, Kobeissi led an effort known as the Skype Open Letter{{cite web|url=http://www.skypeopenletter.com/|title=PHEENIX::SELL|first=|last=Pheenix|website=www.skypeopenletter.com}} which brought together more than forty organizations, including the Electronic Frontier Foundation, [[Reporters Without Borders]], and the [[Open Technology Institute]], calling on [[Microsoft]] and [[Skype]] to release [[Transparency Report|transparency reports]] regarding Skype monitoring and surveillance. The effort was successful, and Microsoft released its first transparency report shortly after the letter was published.{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2013/01/its-time-transparency-reports-become-new-normal|title=It's Time for Transparency Reports to Become the New Normal|date=29 January 2013|publisher=}} ==Controversies== ===Detention and entrapment attempt=== Kobeissi was detained and questioned at the U.S. border by the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|DHS]] in June 2012 about Cryptocat's censorship resistance. He tweeted about the incident afterwards, resulting in media coverage and a spike in the popularity of Cryptocat.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonmatonis/2012/06/07/detaining-developer-at-us-border-increases-cryptocat-popularity|title=Detaining Developer At US Border Increases Cryptocat Popularity|first=Jon|last=Matonis|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.itbusiness.ca/it/client/en/home/News.asp?id=67866|title=Developer’s detention spikes interest in Montreal’s Cryptocat|publisher=}} Kobeissi was regularly searched and questioned whenever he flew in the U.S. in 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/07/crypto-cat-encryption-for-all/|title=This Cute Chat Site Could Save Your Life and Help Overthrow Your Government|publisher=}} In 2012, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] attempted to entrap Kobeissi using [[Sabu (hacktivist)|Sabu]] – an American hacker involved with [[LulzSec]], an offshoot of [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] – as an undercover informant.{{cite news | first=Somini | last=Sengupta | title=A Hacker Charms and Disappoints | url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/12/a-hacker-charms-and-disappoints/ | newspaper=The New York Times |date=12 March 2012}} Kobeissi responded on his blog: "To all young hackers out there – use your talents for research. Never acquiesce to anything illegal with anyone, even if they do it with you."{{Cite web | first=Nadim | last=Kobeissi | title=On Sabu and FBI Entrapment | url=http://log.nadim.cc/?p=65 | publisher=nadim.cc | date=12 March 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618010832/http://log.nadim.cc/?p=65 | archivedate=18 June 2012 | df= }} ===Cryptocat vulnerability=== In mid-2013, critical vulnerabilities were discovered and fixed in the Cryptocat application suite,{{Cite web| title=DecryptoCat | url=http://tobtu.com/decryptocat.php}}{{cite web|url=http://tobtu.com/decryptocat-old.php|title=DecryptoCat - TobTu|website=tobtu.com}} potentially exposing prior communication via the chat program for over a year. The vulnerability was limited to group chat and did not affect private one-on-one conversations.{{cite web|url=https://blog.crypto.cat/2013/07/new-critical-vulnerability-in-cryptocat-details/|title=New Critical Vulnerability in Cryptocat: Details|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705051050/https://blog.crypto.cat/2013/07/new-critical-vulnerability-in-cryptocat-details/|archivedate=2013-07-05|df=}} The ensuing controversy centered on the technical naïveté of Nadim and others who had worked on the project.{{cite news | title=Bad kitty! "Rookie mistake" in Cryptocat chat app makes cracking a snap | url=https://arstechnica.com/security/2013/07/bad-kitty-rooky-mistake-in-cryptocat-chat-app-makes-cracking-a-snap/ }} Steve Thomas, the security researcher who discovered the vulnerabilities, blogged criticizing Cryptocat as "run by people that don't know [[Cryptography|crypto]], make stupid mistakes, and [does not have] enough eyes [that] are looking at their code to find the bugs."{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/07/04/cryptocat_wide_open_new_version_a_must/|title=Cryptocat WIDE OPEN, new version a must|first=Richard Chirgwin 4 Jul 2013 at 22:27|last=tweet_btn()|publisher=}} However, this comment was removed in more recent versions of Thomas's blog post. Meanwhile, other security blogs and news sites called the vulnerability a "responsible disclosure" and praised Cryptocat's transparency regarding vulnerabilities and Kobeissi's warnings regarding the experimental nature of the project.{{cite web|url=https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2013/07/06/cryptocat-encrypted-group-chats-may-have-been-crackable-for-7-months/|title=Cryptocat ‘encrypted’ group chats may have been crackable for 7 months|first=Dubstepcat|last=Says|date=5 July 2013|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.staysmartonline.gov.au/alert_service/alerts/_popular_encrypted_chat_service_cryptocat_contained_a_vulnerability_for_7_months|title=Popular "encrypted chat" service Cryptocat contained a vulnerability for 7 months|first=Stay Smart|last=Online|date=18 July 2013|website=www.staysmartonline.gov.au}} Adam Caudill, an independent security researcher noted that "[Cryptocat developers] didn't understand the data they were working with. [...] anyone [could] crack the keys in a frighteningly short amount of time."{{cite web|url=https://adamcaudill.com/2013/07/04/do-one-thing-right/|title=Do one thing right…|first=Adam|last=Caudill|date=4 July 2013|publisher=}} However, Caudill later also stated that even in light of the controversy, "Cryptocat still achieves its basic goal."{{cite web|url=https://adamcaudill.com/2013/07/16/cryptocat-what-is-the-measure/|title=Cryptocat: What is the measure…|first=Adam|last=Caudill|date=16 July 2013|publisher=}} Kobeissi himself had been vocal in the past about other services using [[encryption]]. In a ''[[Forbes]]'' online article investigating the security of encrypted storage service [[Mega (website)|MEGA]], Kobeissi, who voiced concern along with other security researchers, noted: "It's a nice website, but when it comes to cryptography they seem to have no experience".{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/01/21/researchers-warn-megas-new-encrypted-cloud-cant-keep-its-megasecurity-promises/|title=Researchers Warn: Mega's New Encrypted Cloud Doesn't Keep Its Megasecurity Promises|first=Andy|last=Greenberg|publisher=}} This made Cryptocat's own vulnerabilities a more high-profile discussion among security researchers. Nevertheless, MEGA eventually adopted Kobeissi's critique and implemented the suggested changes to their cryptographic code delivery methods.https://twitter.com/kaepora/status/359684121221537792 === Peerio backdoor claims === In January 2016 Kobeissi tweeted his reasons for leaving [[Peerio]], a cloud-based encrypted communications company he co-founded. These centred around potential plans to sell backdoored versions of the Peerio software to certain clients. Peerio soon denied the claims on their own blog.{{cite web|last1=Grauer|first1=Yael|title=Peerio Co-Founder On Why He Left The Company (Hint: It Had To Do With Admin Backdoors)|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ygrauer/2016/01/25/peerio-co-founder-on-why-he-left-the-company-hint-it-had-to-do-with-admin-backdoors/|website=Forbes.com|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=9 February 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal|Computer security|Internet}} * [[Hacktivism]] * [[Internet activism]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline}} * [https://nadim.computer Personal website] * [https://twitter.com/kaepora Twitter] * [https://crypto.cat Cryptocat] * [http://anapnea.net Anapnea] * [http://rt.com/usa/news/internet-cryptocat-kobeissi-chat-519/ "Online chats, off the record: Cryptocat puts privacy back on the Web"], ''RT'', 20 April 2012. * Curtis, Christopher. [http://www.ottawacitizen.com/technology/touch/6166181/story.html?rel=797532 "Free encryption software Cryptocat protects right to privacy: inventor"], ''Ottawa Citizen'', 17 February 2012. * [http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xjp1b8_nadim-kobeissi-a-student-at-concordia-university-is-helping-to-organize-a-rally-saturday-in-support_news "Nadim Kobeissi, a student at Concordia University, is helping to organize a rally ..."], ''Daily Motion'' (video), 7 March 2011. {{DEFAULTSORT:Kobeissi, Nadim}} [[Category:1990 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Computer security specialists]] [[Category:Lebanese American University alumni]] [[Category:Concordia University alumni]] [[Category:Lebanese expatriates]] [[Category:People from Beirut]]

{{Simpsons character | image=Nelson Muntz.PNG | image size = 160 | name=Nelson Muntz | gender=Male | job= Student at [[Springfield Elementary School]] | relatives='''Father''': Mr. Eddie Muntz
'''Mother''': [[Mrs. Muntz|Mrs. Marilyn Muntz]]
'''Grandfather''': Judge Muntz
'''Sister:''' unnamed | alsoknownas=Smelson | appearance="[[Bart the General]]" | voiceactor=[[Nancy Cartwright]] }} '''Nelson Muntz'''{{cite episode|title=Loan-a Lisa|series=The Simpsons|date=October 3, 2010|number=466|season=22|credits=Garza, Valentina; Faughnan, Matthew|network=Fox}} is a [[fictional character]] and the lead school bully from the [[animated television series]] ''[[The Simpsons]]'', best known for his signature mocking laugh "Ha-ha!". He is voiced by [[Nancy Cartwright]] and was introduced in Season 1's "[[Bart the General]]" as an [[antagonist]] but later turned into an on-and-off friend of [[Bart Simpson]]. ==Role in ''The Simpsons''== Nelson is a student and [[Bullying|bully]] at [[Springfield Elementary School]]. He is known to have terrorized virtually every kid in [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]] at one point or another. Most often, however, it is the school nerds and less popular students, such as [[Milhouse Van Houten|Milhouse]] and [[Martin Prince|Martin]], who are the subject of his cruelty. Nelson shows the occasional glimpse of humanity, though, and other characters have occasionally warmed to him; Lisa dates him briefly in "[[Lisa's Date with Density]]", [[Marge Simpson|Marge]] informally adopts him in "[[Sleeping with the Enemy (The Simpsons)|Sleeping with the Enemy]]", and Bart is shown as a friend to him several times, such as in "[[The Haw-Hawed Couple]]". His family life is dysfunctional. While some early episodes offer inconsistent histories (such as [[Lisa's Date with Density|Nelson's dad going insane and abandoning him]], [[A Milhouse Divided|Nelson's parents divorcing because of his mom's cough drop addiction]], or [[Bart the Mother|Nelson's dad in prison while his mom "has bigger problems"]]), the [[Canon (fiction)|canon]] story that has evolved is that he lives in a dilapidated house with his mother who works on the fringes of the sex industry, either as a waitress at [[Hooters]] or in a topless bar. The [[Characterisation|character design]] and voice portrayal of both parents has varied throughout the course of the series. It is shown in many episodes that Nelson's father abandoned him and his mother at an early age when he "went to pick up some [[Pop-Tarts]]" although, later on in the series, he was said to have gone to pick up a pack of cigarettes. In the fourth-season episode "[[Brother from the Same Planet]]", Nelson's father is the children's soccer coach who awards Nelson with a free trip to Pele's Soccer and Acting Camp. Nelson's father also appears briefly in the sixth-season episode "[[Bart's Girlfriend]]"; depicted capturing Nelson with a leash as the children run through the cornfields in an attempt to avoid attending church. He also appears in the ninth-season episode "[[Bart Star]]" to congratulate Nelson after a football game victory and take him to Hooters (with Nelson turning down the invitation because he "doesn't want to see [his] Mom at work"). Nelson's father returns in the sixteenth-season episode "[[Sleeping with the Enemy (The Simpsons)|Sleeping with the Enemy]]". It turns out that he did not leave Nelson deliberately; he bit into a chocolate bar, not knowing it had peanuts and had an [[Anaphylaxis|allergic reaction]], covering 90% of his body with large [[tumors]]. Looking like [[Joseph Merrick]], he ran out of the store and encountered a circus that made him a part of its [[freak show]]. At performances, circus attendees threw peanuts at him, which perpetuated his reaction, preventing him from returning to normal. When the circus came through Springfield, Bart recognized him and brought him home to rid himself of Nelson (who had been taken into the Simpson home by Marge). Nelson is also a natural athlete. In the episode "[[Bart Star]]", Nelson almost singlehandedly carries the entire Springfield Pee-Wee football team. As the team quarterback, he also on one occasion catches his own pass and plows through the opposing team with extreme ease. In various episodes, he gives out the impression that he is a lot smarter than he may first appear. Nelson often points out painfully obvious things to adults and kids alike that take them longer to grasp. Another example is a running joke where Nelson does a class assignment that is implied to be of high quality. However, he is always brushed off by the teachers before he gets to show them his work. Another running joke, though, is Nelson presenting ridiculously simple assignments, such as repeatedly showing a can of tomato paste in Show and Tell, and a presentation on ''[[The Grapes of Wrath]]'', consisting of himself crushing a bunch of grapes with a hammer, stating "Here's the grapes, and here's the wrath!" In later episodes, Nelson shows signs of being a tormented artist type, even [[Any Given Sundance|submitting a film]] to the [[Sundance Film Festival]] about his life as a child living in poverty with a single, unfit mother and no strong father figure. He memorably says in the documentary, "I like to cry at the ocean, because only there do my tears seem small."{{cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2008/05/04/the-simpsons-any-given-sundance/ |title=The Simpsons: Any Given Sundance — VIDEO |publisher=Tvsquad.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-26}} In the episode "[[Little Big Girl]]", it is revealed that Nelson is German-American. Ironically, in "[[Much Apu About Nothing]]", Nelson picks on foreign exchange student [[Üter Zörker|Üter]] for being German during Springfield's anti-immigration mania. He is shown to be a big fan of [[Andy Williams]] as he, Bart, Milhouse and Martin went to a concert performed by him in "[[Bart on the Road]]". ==Relationships with other characters== Even though in the first season (and for many seasons afterwards) Nelson seemed to be [[Bart Simpson|Bart]]'s antagonist, he eventually becomes what can be considered as Bart's second closest friend after Milhouse. In [[Bart the General|his debut episode]], Lisa was the initial target of Nelson's bullying, which prompted Bart to defend her. Bart's actions resulted in frequent beatings by Nelson and his gang, but finally ended when Bart received help from [[List of recurring The Simpsons characters|Herman]], who came up with the idea of standing up to Nelson and his gang by pelting them with [[water balloon]]s. From that point on, Nelson shows a grudging respect for Bart, though he occasionally reverts to his past behavior towards him. Although still prone to violence, Nelson hangs out with Bart and his less popular friends, such as [[Milhouse Van Houten]] and occasionally even common bullying target [[Martin Prince]]. In "[[The Debarted]]", it is shown that Nelson has become Bart's "other best friend", along with Milhouse. Nelson has many other moments where he displays his hidden good nature, such as his brief amorous relationship with Lisa. Although he cannot control his delinquent tendencies, he treats her with respect and even tries to change for her, although both of them realize that he is not being true to himself by doing so. In "[[Lisa's Date with Density]]", Nelson kisses Lisa, only to be berated by [[Jimbo Jones|Jimbo]], [[Kearney Zzyzwicz|Kearney]], and [[Dolph Starbeam|Dolph]], who believe that kissing girls is "[[gay]]" (despite the events that occurred revolving around Jimbo in "[[New Kid On The Block]]"). He also punishes [[Sherri and Terri]] for tormenting Lisa. Another curious example of his "good side" is with Martin, a boy whom Nelson picks on perhaps more so than any other kid in town. Despite the utter cruelty, there are occasional hints that Nelson does not harbor any real hatred towards Martin and only does so to maintain his 'tough guy' reputation. In "[[Dial 'N' for Nerder]]", when it is believed that Martin has died, Nelson endeavours to learn the truth and find Martin's killers. When it is revealed that Martin is alive, Nelson mocks and punches him, but also states that he is glad Martin is not dead. In this same episode, however, when Lisa tries to bribe him to not rat her out by offering to get back together with him, he rejects it. In another episode, it is revealed that both Martin and Nelson went to space camp, and that Nelson was a loyal officer to Martin. (See "[[I'm Spelling as Fast as I Can]]") In "[[Loan-a Lisa]]", Lisa uses $50 to help Nelson fund his bicycle company, which becomes a success. When Nelson almost drops out of school to spend more time on the company, Lisa is saddened and attempts to stop him from doing so, but eventually respects his decision after realising he won't change despite the money used to fund it. Nelson eventually decides not to drop out after all and takes Lisa skating to make it up to her. Though Nelson is often said to not really have friends aside from his on-and-off relationship with Bart and the others, Nelson sometimes hangs out with his fellow school bullies [[Jimbo Jones|Jimbo]], [[Dolph Starbeam|Dolph]], [[Kearney Zzyzwicz|Kearney]], and (to a lesser extent) two smaller and younger fraternal twin minions known as the Weasels. Though only seen with them occasionally, Nelson is also ironically the leader of the school bullies (possibly by virtue of being the most often seen and most recognizable of the gang). In "[[Sleeping with the Enemy (The Simpsons)|Sleeping with the Enemy]]", [[Moe Szyslak]] appears briefly during a Muntz family reunion. The facial similarities between Moe and the Muntz are surprisingly quite apparent and Moe's childhood experiences and behaviors are somewhat relatable with Nelson's. Moe briefly appears and claims that he is part of the family and is then shunned off screen by the Muntz' confused looks. ==Character== [[File:Nancy Cartwright.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Nancy Cartwright]] voices Nelson, even though the role wasn't assigned to her originally.]] ''[[The Simpsons]]'' creator [[Matt Groening]] named Nelson after the [[Nelson hold|wrestling hold of the same name]].Groening, Matt (2004). Commentary for the episode "[[Lady Bouvier's Lover]]", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fifth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. Nelson was also said to be named after popular [[Brat Pack (actors)|Brat Pack]] actor [[Judd Nelson]], who portrayed the character John Bender in the eighties classic ''[[The Breakfast Club]]'', partially of whom Nelson Muntz's character has similarities. Cast member [[Nancy Cartwright]] voices the character, which first appeared in the fifth episode of the first season, "[[Bart the General]]" (1990). American voice actress [[Dana Hill]] was first supposed to provide Nelson's voice, and attended the [[read-through]] of the episode. However, as Cartwright wrote in her autobiography ''[[My Life as a 10-Year-Old Boy]]'', "the producers were still putting together this ensemble of [actors] and, come Monday, at the recording, she was nowhere to be found and the part was assigned to me. I didn't have time to ask why and I still don't have a clue."{{cite book |title= [[My Life as a 10-Year-Old Boy]]|last= Cartwright|first= Nancy|authorlink= Nancy Cartwright|chapter=Lady, That Ain't No Gutterball!|pages=102–103|year= 2000|publisher=[[Hyperion (publisher)|Hyperion]]|isbn=0-7868-8600-5}} Cartwright also commented that when she first found out she would be voicing Nelson, "I asked myself, 'What does a bully sound like?' Well... what you hear is what you get. When I first uttered, 'I'll get you after school, man!' I let out a sigh of relief when I got through the line and a double-sigh when it got a laugh." By the [[The Simpsons (season 8)|eighth season]] of ''The Simpsons'', the [[List of writers of The Simpsons|writers]] had begun to explore the secondary characters of the show. "[[Lisa's Date with Density]]" (season eighth, 1996) was the first episode to center around Nelson and was used to explain why he acts the way he does. The idea of Nelson dating [[Lisa Simpson]] had already been around for a while, but this was the first time that the staff worked it into the show.Scully, Mike; Weinstein, Josh (2007). Commentary for the episode "[[Lisa's Date with Density]]", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Eighth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. Cartwright said in 2012 that she thinks Nelson "has evolved the most out of all the characters I do. There's a soft spot in him that the writers have found. He's got this special attraction to Marge, and he sings these songs, and he's got a crush on Lisa. There's something about this poor kid – his mother works at Hooters, his dad went out to buy milk and never came back. I wouldn't want him to come over for dinner, but I really love doing his voice."{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Stacey|title='The Simpsons' at 500: Untold Stories|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/simpsons-500-episodes-conan-obrien-matt-groening-287864?page=2|accessdate=2012-02-08|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2012-02-08}} ==Reception== The episode "[[The Haw-Hawed Couple]]" in 2007 was nominated for the [[Emmy Award]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (for Programming Less Than One Hour)|Outstanding Animated Program]].[http://www.cdn.emmys.tv/downloads/2007/59ptemmys_noms.pdf 59th Primetime Emmy Nominations], emmys.tv. Retrieved on 2008-07-11 {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}[http://www.simpsonschannel.com/cgi-bin/newspro/addons/iSay.cgi?Page=Comments&ID=EElulyVZAywIxXpZtp Simpsons Channel | Simpsons Nominated For Emmy Award] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110060918/http://www.simpsonschannel.com/cgi-bin/newspro/addons/iSay.cgi?Page=Comments&ID=EElulyVZAywIxXpZtp |date=January 10, 2009 }} The writer of the episode [[Matt Selman]] was nominated for a [[Writers Guild of America Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wga.org/awards/awardssub.aspx?id=1516 |title=Writer's Guild Awards — Television Nominees 2008 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120525035829/http://www.wga.org/awards/awardssub.aspx?id=1516 |archivedate=2012-05-25 |deadurl=no |df= }}, Writer's Guild of America West. Retrieved on 2008-07-11 In his review of the season 22 episode "[[Loan-a Lisa]]", Rowan Kaiser of [[The A.V. Club]] commented that Nelson's character has undergone a "[[tvtropes:BadassDecay|Spikeification]]", in reference to the bully's near-exclusive portrayal as being likable and vulnerable in later seasons of the program.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/loanalisacleveland-liveexcellence-in-broadcasting1,45839/|title="Loan-a-Lisa"/"Cleveland Live!"/"Excellence in Broadcasting"/"100 A.D., Pt 1 of 2"|last=Kaiser|first=Rowan|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=[[The Onion]]|accessdate=2010-10-04|date=2010-10-04}} ==In popular culture== * In 2016, independent recording artist, @Kendallisall, used a photo of Nelson for the cover of his single "Ha Ha" released to [[SoundCloud]], which received 22.4 thousand streams. This trend was followed by artists DDG ("Lettuce"), [[Famous Dex]] ("Ok Dexter"), [[Rich the Kid]] (''[[Rich Forever 3]]'') and [[Ugly God]] ("[[Water (Ugly God song)|Water]]"), who's single covers depicted re-imagined interpretations of characters from other animated television series. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|The Simpsons|Fictional characters}} {{Simpsons characters}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Muntz, Nelson}} [[Category:The Simpsons characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1990]] [[Category:Child characters in television]] [[Category:Child characters in animated films]] [[Category:Fictional bullies]] [[Category:Fictional American people of German descent]] [[Category:Male characters in animation]] [[de:Figuren aus Die Simpsons#Nelson Muntz]]
